Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Hypertension, swelling in legs, and proteinuria for 2 weeks

Present Illness.Onset: Approximately 2 weeks ago, at home, gradually with no apparent trigger
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Persistent hypertension, notable leg edema, proteinuria detected upon testing; symptoms worsening over the past week despite rest
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Occasional headaches, dizziness predominantly when standing up
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Initial consultation with primary care physician led to diagnosis of Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension Syndrome. Prescribed medication and advised bed rest. Symptoms did not improve significantly. Referral to hospital for further management.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state slightly anxious due to health concerns. Sleep disturbed by discomfort. Appetite decreased slightly. No significant changes in urination and defecation patterns. Mild weight gain attributed to edema.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally healthy with no significant past illnesses
Past History.Immunization History: Up to date with standard immunizations

Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Works as a teacher, generally sedentary lifestyle
Personal History.Exposure History: No known exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances
Personal History.Travel History: No significant travel history in the past year

Marital and Family History.Family History: Mother has hypertension, father healthy, no siblings

Systematic Examination.Neck: No goiter, no jugular venous distention
Systematic Examination.Chest: Clear lung sounds, no murmurs or added heart sounds
Systematic Examination.Limbs: Pitting edema observed in lower extremities

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Ophthalmologic examination: No retinopathy; significant pitting edema in lower limbs
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Urinalysis: Proteinuria 2+, Blood tests: Elevated serum creatinine, Ultrasonography: Normal fetal growth and development
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on patient's history, presence of hypertension (BP 150/95 mmHg), proteinuria, and edema in a previously normotensive patient
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Chronic hypertension (ruled out by lack of pre-pregnancy history and normal baseline tests), preeclampsia (symptoms not severe enough nor congruent progression), chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia (ruled out by onset timing and previous history)

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient admitted with signs of Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension Syndrome. Initial management includes bed rest, antihypertensive therapy, and monitoring fetal well-being. Differential diagnosis includes chronic hypertension and preeclampsia. Further diagnostic tests pending.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Daily assessments show consistent BP readings around 145-150/90-95 mmHg with no significant headaches or visual disturbances. Fetal movements normal, mild persistence of edema.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Reviewed patient's ongoing symptoms and test results; current management plan reaffirmed, discussed need for close monitoring due to risk of progression to preeclampsia.
Post-Admission Course Records.Difficult Case Discussion Records: Interdisciplinary meeting discussed patient’s risk profile and potential need for early induction of labor if symptoms worsen.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Next shift briefed on patient’s stable, but closely monitored condition, ongoing need for fetal heart monitoring and periodic blood tests.
Post-Admission Course Records.Transfer Records: No transfer required, patient remains in obstetric care unit.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: End of week summary: Patient remains stable, BP under control, no signs of eclampsia onset, continuation of current management plan with scheduled ultrasound.
Post-Admission Course Records.Emergency Records: No emergencies recorded during this period.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Cardiology consulted regarding management of hypertensive state, no additional medications prescribed at this time.

Surgery Related.Preoperative Summary: Indicated for cesarean section due to non-progression of attempts at labor induction and worsening hypertension.
Surgery Related.Preoperative Discussion Records: Discussion on choice of cesarean section, possible complications including further rise in BP, bleeding risks.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Preoperative Visit Records: Patient assessed for anesthesia, deemed fit for spinal anesthesia but with close monitoring due to hypertension.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Records: Spinal anesthesia administered without complications, patient remained stable throughout the procedure.
Surgery Related.Surgery Records: Cesarean section performed, delivery of healthy infant, minor blood loss, patient stable.
Surgery Related.Surgery Safety Checklist: Completed; patient identity, surgical site, and anesthesia verified pre-surgery.
Surgery Related.Surgery Instrument Count Records: All instruments and items accounted for post-surgery.
Surgery Related.Postoperative First Course Record: Patient transferred to recovery, stable vitals, ongoing assessment for any signs of postpartum complications.
Surgery Related.Anesthesia Postoperative Visit Records: Patient shows good recovery post-anesthesia, all vitals stable, minimal pain.

Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Planned for discharge after 4 days post-surgery with instructions on monitoring BP and follow-up in 1 week.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: Bed rest, ongoing antihypertensive medication, daily BP monitoring, regular fetal cardiac monitoring
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: Immediate cesarean section due to non-progress of labor induction and maternal hypertension

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: Ultrasound: Normal fetal growth; lab tests: Normal liver function, elevated uric acid, proteinuria 2+
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Temperature stable, BP readings consistently around 145-150/90-95 mmHg, Pulse 88 bpm, Respiration 18 breaths/min
Hospitalization Record.Blood Transfusion Consent: Signed in the event of surgical necessity
Hospitalization Record.Special Examination Consent: Signed for detailed fetal monitoring and blood tests

Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperiu.Name: Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension Syndrome
Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperiu.Differential Diagnosis: Chronic hypertension, preeclampsia, chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.
